subject: Government
instructions: Attempt all questions from this section

questions.question: The principle of separation of powers, as outlined in the U.S. Constitution, was primarily influenced by the writings of:
questions.answer: Montesquieu

questions.question: The Federalist Papers were written to:
options: Advocate for the ratification of the Constitution
questions.answer: Advocate for the ratification of the Constitution

questions.question: Under the Great Compromise at the Constitutional Convention, the number of representatives in the House of Representatives is based on:
questions.answer: Population size

questions.question: The Supremacy Clause in Article VI establishes that:
options: Federal law is the supreme law of the land
States have veto power over federal laws
The judiciary is subordinate to the executive
questions.answer: Federal law is the supreme law of the land

questions.question: The Anti-Federalists' primary concern with the Constitution was the lack of:
questions.answer: Protections for individual rights

questions.question: A bill becomes law after passing both houses of Congress and:
options: Being signed by the president or not vetoed within 10 days
questions.answer: Being signed by the president or not vetoed within 10 days

questions.question: The filibuster in the Senate can be ended by:
questions.answer: A three-fifths cloture vote

questions.question: Gerrymandering refers to the manipulation of:
options: Congressional district boundaries for partisan advantage
questions.answer: Congressional district boundaries for partisan advantage

questions.question: The power of the purse, which allows Congress to control federal spending, is derived from:
questions.answer: Article I, Section 9

questions.question: Standing committees in Congress primarily handle:
options: Routine legislative oversight and bill review
questions.answer: Routine legislative oversight and bill review

questions.question: The War Powers Resolution of 1973 requires the president to:
options: Consult Congress before introducing troops into hostilities
Seek congressional approval for all military actions
Report to Congress within 48 hours of committing forces
Limit deployments to 60 days without declaration
questions.answer: Report to Congress within 48 hours of committing forces

questions.question: Logrolling in Congress involves:
options: Mutual support for each other's legislative priorities
questions.answer: Mutual support for each other's legislative priorities

questions.question: The president's veto can be overridden by:
options: A simple majority in both houses of Congress
A two-thirds vote in both houses of Congress
questions.answer: A two-thirds vote in both houses of Congress

questions.question: Executive orders derive their authority from:
questions.answer: Article II of the Constitution

questions.question: The Cabinet secretaries are appointed by the president and confirmed by:
questions.answer: The Senate

questions.question: The Bully Pulpit refers to the president's use of:
options: Media and public opinion to advance agenda
questions.answer: Media and public opinion to advance agenda

questions.question: Impoundment of funds by the president was limited by the:
options: Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974
questions.answer: Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974

questions.question: The role of the vice president in the Senate is to:
options: Preside and vote only to break ties
questions.answer: Preside and vote only to break ties

questions.question: Judicial review was established by the Supreme Court in:
questions.answer: Marbury v. Madison (1803)

questions.question: The doctrine of stare decisis means:
options: Courts follow precedents set by prior decisions
Judges must recuse themselves in conflicts
Appeals go directly to the Supreme Court
questions.answer: Courts follow precedents set by prior decisions

questions.question: Original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court applies to cases involving:
questions.answer: Ambassadors or states as parties

questions.question: The writ of habeas corpus can be suspended by:
options: Congress in cases of rebellion or invasion
questions.answer: Congress in cases of rebellion or invasion

questions.question: Strict constructionism in judicial interpretation emphasizes:
questions.answer: Original intent of the Constitution

questions.question: The 10th Amendment reserves powers not delegated to the federal government to:
questions.answer: The states or the people

questions.question: Cooperative federalism is characterized by:
options: Shared responsibilities between federal and state governments (e.g., grants-in-aid)
questions.answer: Shared responsibilities between federal and state governments (e.g., grants-in-aid)

questions.question: In a unitary system of government, power is:
options: Divided equally between national and regional levels
questions.answer: Concentrated at the national level

questions.question: The full faith and credit clause requires states to:
options: Honor public acts, records, and judicial proceedings of other states
questions.answer: Honor public acts, records, and judicial proceedings of other states

questions.question: The First Amendment protects freedom of speech but allows restrictions for:
options: Clear and present danger (Schenck v. United States)
questions.answer: Clear and present danger (Schenck v. United States)

questions.question: The Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment was used in Brown v. Board of Education to end:
questions.answer: Segregated public schools

questions.question: Suspect classifications under strict scrutiny include:
questions.answer: Race and national origin

questions.question: The right to privacy, implied in the Bill of Rights, was affirmed in:
questions.answer: Griswold v. Connecticut (contraception)

questions.question: Affirmative action programs must meet:
options: Strict scrutiny to remedy past discrimination
questions.answer: Strict scrutiny to remedy past discrimination

questions.question: The Voting Rights Act of 1965 targeted:
options: Literacy tests and poll taxes in discriminatory jurisdictions
questions.answer: Literacy tests and poll taxes in discriminatory jurisdictions

questions.question: The Electoral College allocates electors based on:
questions.answer: Congressional representation (senators + representatives)

questions.question: Soft money in campaigns refers to:
options: Unlimited contributions to political parties for party-building activities
questions.answer: Unlimited contributions to political parties for party-building activities

questions.question: Interest groups primarily influence policy through:
questions.answer: Lobbying, litigation, and mobilization

questions.question: The spoils system was replaced by the:
questions.answer: Pendleton Civil Service Act (merit-based appointments)

questions.question: Public opinion polls measure attitudes but are limited by:
questions.answer: Sampling errors and question wording

questions.question: Fiscal federalism involves:
options: Federal grants to states for specific purposes (categorical grants)
questions.answer: Federal grants to states for specific purposes (categorical grants)

questions.question: The iron triangle in public policy consists of:
options: Congressional committees, bureaucratic agencies, and interest groups
questions.answer: Congressional committees, bureaucratic agencies, and interest groups
